techs.name: Formation of Earth
techs.quote: Earth formed from the accretion of dust and gas in the solar nebula.

techs.name: Moon Formation
techs.quote: A collision with a Mars-sized body called Theia led to the formation of the Moon.

techs.name: Volcanic Activity
techs.quote: Intense volcanic activity and frequent collisions with other celestial bodies.

techs.name: Formation of Crust
techs.quote: Cooling of the Earth’s surface led to the formation of a solid crust.

techs.name: Primordial Atmosphere
techs.quote: Volcanic outgassing created an atmosphere rich in carbon dioxide, water vapor, and other gases.

techs.name: Oceans
techs.quote: Condensation of water vapor led to the formation of the first oceans.

techs.name: Stabilization of Crust
techs.quote: Formation of the first stable continental crusts.

techs.name: Plate Tectonics
techs.quote: Early evidence of plate tectonic activity.

techs.name: Formation of Atmosphere
techs.quote: Gradual changes in the atmosphere, still lacking significant oxygen.

techs.name: First Life Forms
techs.quote: Emergence of simple, single-celled organisms like bacteria and archaea.

techs.name: Photosynthesis
techs.quote: Development of photosynthetic bacteria, leading to the production of oxygen.

techs.name: Stromatolites
techs.quote: Formation of stromatolites, layered structures created by microbial communities.

techs.name: Eukaryotes
techs.quote: Emergence of eukaryotic cells, which have a nucleus and organelles.

techs.name: Continental Growth
techs.quote: Further stabilization and growth of continental landmasses.

techs.name: Multicellular Life
techs.quote: Development of multicellular organisms.

techs.name: Oxygenation
techs.quote: Significant increase in atmospheric oxygen, known as the Great Oxidation Event.

techs.name: Symbiosis
techs.quote: Evolution of symbiotic relationships, such as those between mitochondria and their host cells.

techs.name: Cambrian Explosion
techs.quote: A dramatic increase in the diversity of life forms, including the first appearance of many major groups of animals.

techs.name: Trilobites
techs.quote: These were among the most successful and diverse groups of early arthropods, dominating the Cambrian seas.

techs.name: First Vertebrates
techs.quote: Early fish-like creatures with primitive backbones appeared, marking the beginning of vertebrate evolution.

techs.name: Complex Ecosystems
techs.quote: The Cambrian seas were teeming with life, including predators like Anomalocaris and various types of prey, leading to complex food webs.

techs.name: Marine Biodiversity
techs.quote: The Ordovician saw a significant increase in marine biodiversity, with the appearance of new species of brachiopods, bryozoans, mollusks, and the first coral reefs.

techs.name: First Land Plants
techs.quote: Simple plants like mosses and liverworts began to colonize land, setting the stage for more complex terrestrial ecosystems.

techs.name: Glaciation and Mass Extinction
techs.quote: The Ordovician period ended with a major glaciation event that caused a significant drop in sea levels and a mass extinction, wiping out many marine species.

techs.name: Diversification of Jawed Fish
techs.quote: The first jawed fish appeared, leading to a greater variety of marine predators.

techs.name: Terrestrial Ecosystems
techs.quote: Vascular plants with specialized tissues for transporting water and nutrients began to spread on land, along with the first terrestrial arthropods like millipedes and early arachnids.

techs.name: Formation of Laurussia
uniques: [+1 Culture] from [Ocean] tiles [in all cities] <during the [Devonian]>
techs.quote: This sets the stage for the warm climate and shallow seas.

techs.name: Warm Climate
techs.quote: The warm climate supports the diversification of marine life and the spread of early plants.

techs.name: Seed Plants
techs.quote: The first forests create an environment where seed plants can evolve.

techs.name: Land Arthropods
techs.quote: The presence of plants on land provides food and habitat for arthropods.

techs.name: Amphibians
techs.quote: The earliest well-known amphibian, Ichthyostega, was found in Late Devonian deposits in Greenland, dating back about 363 million years. The earliest amphibian discovered to date is Elginerpeton, found in Late Devonian rocks of Scotland dating to approximately 368 million years ago.

techs.name: Placodermi
techs.quote: Placoderms were among the first jawed fish (their jaws likely evolved from the first pair of gill arches), as well as the first vertebrates to have true teeth. They were also the first fish clade to develop pelvic fins, the second set of paired fins and the homologous precursor to hindlimbs in tetrapods. 380-million-year-old fossils of three other genera, Incisoscutum, Materpiscis and Austroptyctodus, represent the oldest known examples of live birth.

techs.name: Early Trees
techs.quote: The earliest-known trees appeared in the Middle Devonian. These included a lineage of lycopods and another arborescent, woody vascular plant, the cladoxylopsids and progymnosperm Archaeopteris.

techs.name: Red Sandstone
uniques: [+1 Culture] from [Sand] tiles [in all cities] <during the [Devonian]>
techs.quote: Old Red Sandstone, abbreviated ORS, is an assemblage of rocks in the North Atlantic region largely of Devonian age. It extends in the east across Great Britain, Ireland and Norway, and in the west along the eastern seaboard of North America. It also extends northwards into Greenland and Svalbard.

techs.name: Ammonites
techs.quote: Ammonite is actually the colloquial term for ammonoids, a large and diverse group of creatures that arose during the Devonian period, which began about 416 million years ago. Ammonoids are related to other cephalopods—such as squid, octopuses, and cuttlefish—and they were early relatives of the modern nautilus.

techs.name: Late Devonian Extinction
techs.quote: The Late Devonian extinction, which started about 375 Ma, severely affected marine life, killing off most of the reef systems, most of the jawless fish, half of all placoderms, and nearly all trilobites save for a few species of the order Proetida. The subsequent end-Devonian extinction, which occurred at around 359 Ma, further impacted the ecosystems and completed the extinction of all calcite sponge reefs and placoderms. Conclude with the significant extinction events, such as the Kellwasser and Hangenberg events, which affected marine life and marked the end of the Devonian.

techs.name: Rise of Coal Forests
techs.quote: Introduce the extensive coal forests that characterized the early Carboniferous, setting the stage for the next era.

techs.name: Amphibian Proliferation
techs.quote: Amphibians thrived due to the abundant water bodies in forests.

techs.name: Large Tree Ferns
techs.quote: Massive ferns thriving in the swampy conditions of the coal swamps.

techs.name: Pangea
techs.quote: Slow movement of tectonic plates beginning to form the supercontinent.

techs.name: Limestone Formations
uniques: [+2 Culture] from [Limestone] tiles [in all cities] <during the [Carboniferous]>
[+1 Production] from [Iron] tiles [in all cities] <during the [Carboniferous]>
techs.quote: Limestone formed in shallow seas that sometimes overlapped with coal swamps.

techs.name: Early Reptiles
techs.quote: Reptiles evolved from amphibians, adapting to less water-dependent lifestyles.

techs.name: Extensive Rivers
techs.quote: Rivers formed as a result of the dense vegetation altering water flows.

techs.name: Increased Atmospheric Oxygen
techs.quote: Dense forests photosynthesized heavily, increasing oxygen levels.

techs.name: Insect Gigantism
techs.quote: Higher oxygen levels allowed insects to grow to enormous sizes.

techs.name: Carboniferous Mountains
techs.quote: Tectonic collisions during Pangaea's formation created new mountain ranges.

techs.name: Southern Hemisphere Ice Sheets
techs.quote: Glaciers expanded, causing changes in sea levels and climate.

techs.name: Sedimentation
techs.quote: Erosion from mountains deposited sediments in nearby seas.

techs.name: Diversification
techs.quote: Changing sea levels and new sedimentary environments fostered diverse marine ecosystems.

techs.name: Roots
techs.quote: Plant roots helped in the creation of soil by breaking down rocks and organic matter.

techs.name: Fossilization
techs.quote: Buried organic material in sediments eventually became fossils.

techs.name: Lycophytes and Horsetails
techs.quote: These plants thrived in the moist conditions of the coal swamps.

techs.name: Siberia
techs.quote: Nowadays Eurasia were Permian Landmasses (Siberia, Kazakhstania and others).

techs.name: Panthalassa Ocean
techs.quote: The vast ocean that surrounded Pangea, covering much of the Earth’s surface.

techs.name: Desertification
techs.quote: Expansion of arid environments due to climate changes, leading to widespread deserts.

techs.name: Reduction of Coal Swamps
techs.quote: Decline of the lush Carboniferous coal swamps as the climate became drier.

techs.name: Development of Conifer Forests
techs.quote: Conifers became more prominent, adapting to the drier conditions.

techs.name: Marine Reefs
techs.quote: Development of extensive reef systems, which later declined towards the end of the period.

techs.name: Thermal Maximum
techs.quote: Periods of extreme global warming, affecting both marine and terrestrial life.

techs.name: Fluctuations in Oxygen Levels
techs.quote: Changes in atmospheric oxygen levels, impacting the evolution and survival of species.

techs.name: Permian Volcanic Activity
techs.quote: Extensive volcanic eruptions, particularly in the Siberian Traps, releasing massive amounts of lava and gases.

techs.name: Early Mammal Ancestors
techs.quote: Therapsids evolved, leading to early mammal-like reptiles.

techs.name: Expansion of Arid Regions
uniques: [+1 Culture] from [Sand] tiles [in all cities] <during the [Permian]>
techs.quote: Increased desertification across Pangea, leading to more extensive dry areas.

techs.name: Development of Salt Deposits
techs.quote: Formation of large salt deposits in evaporating inland seas.

techs.name: Formation of Mountain Ranges
uniques: [+1 Culture] from [Mountain] tiles [in all cities] <during the [Permian]>
techs.quote: Orogenic events leading to the formation of mountain ranges, reshaping the landscape.

techs.name: Evolution of Insects
techs.quote: Rapid evolution and diversification of insects, adapting to new ecological niches.

techs.name: Decline of Marine Biodiversity
techs.quote: Reduction in marine species diversity leading up to the mass extinction.

techs.name: The Great Dying
techs.quote: Approximately 251.9 million years ago, the Permian–Triassic extinction event; also known as the Late Permian extinction event, the Latest Permian extinction event, the End-Permian extinction event, and colloquially as the Great Dying) forms the boundary between the Permian and Triassic geologic periods, and with them the Paleozoic and Mesozoic eras. It is Earth's most severe known extinction event, with the extinction of 57% of biological families, 83% of genera, 81% of marine species and 70% of terrestrial vertebrate species. It is also the greatest known mass extinction of insects. It is the greatest of the Big Five mass extinctions of the Phanerozoic. There is evidence for one to three distinct pulses, or phases, of extinction.
